B000067FP8|5.0|Gremlins 2 should definately be considered a superior sequel. Everything about this movie is top notch and for B-flicks that usually is not the case. Even the critics who despised the first Gremlins gave this movie good reviews. So much creativity was put into this film that it surprises me Spielburg didn't return to the project(Joe Dante did return). Everything from character development, stage settings, the music, and overall story were well thought out and you can tell that the actors enjoyed playing their parts and had a good time on the set. Gremlins 2 by no means takes itself too seriously. The first portion of the movie gives you the impression that it will be rushed though it doesn't end up that way. Four of the characters including Gizmo return from the first Gremlins and the gremlins themselves are designed a bit differently though it is definately for the better. Regarding my comment on the creativity of this movie, you must see it for yourself. This gremlins sequel (superior sequel, mind you) gets the DVD treatment it deserves like Terminator 2 did in terms of bonus features (okay, Terminator 2 had alot more but you get my point). Each feature is worth viewing and there are also some easter eggs a.k.a hidden features. At first I hoped for a Gremlins 3 but I don't see how it would rank up with this one. Even if you happened to not care much for the first Gremlins, you still should give Gremlins 2 a look. I honestly know someone who didn't care too much for Gremlins but told me they really enjoyed the sequel.
B000AMJDHY|5.0|Chicago is an interesting city nowadays. They seem to be training these kids to live and breathe hooks, high pitched vocals, and randomly non-conventional music. Fall Out Boy put out their pop masterpiece with From Under the Cork Tree. The Academy Is... put out a debut that easily equals the pop princesses and princes with double the amount of talent. OK Go took the more rock-pop approach. And now this. Now before you all go and start to say I am not helpful and that i am a poser who has succumbed to pop-punk as my favorite music. Its not true. now please read on <br /> <br />after the intro, the album starts out with a kick. from the first notes i knew i had found a new guilty pleasure. little did i know, that this album never falters. their slightly unnecesarily long, yet occasionally witty, titles are part of the new fad. like most of what Panic does, however, they do it almost better than anyone. the next song has a little bit of a bite to it, but retains the hooks that you will grow to love. Nails for Breakfast, Tacks for Snacks is one of the most synthy of the songs, and is also relatively slow. The following track is my least favorite song on the album, but it certainly has its high points. but these first few songs are simply to get you ready for their style. now for the real good songs <br /> <br />Starting with Time to Dance, the album truly picks up. Time to Dance is an aptly named song with memorable lines (When I say shotgun you say wedding), danceable beats in tune with lyrical hooks, and intelligently designed instrumentation. This is my favorite track on the album. Lying is the Most Fun a Girl Can Have really caught my eye on the cd because it is a wonderful allusion to the movie Closer, which is one of my favorite movies of all time. It starts out tantalizingly low, with the singer having all of the bravado and arrogance of musicians with much more experience that he. Yelling \\"lets get these teen hearts beating faster, faster\\", you believe the yearning to get people dancing. Intermission is a lyricless, electronica-based powerhouse showing off that the techno beats aren't just a whim <br /> <br />But It Better If You Do (a continuation of the line from Closer), is a funny, fast paced song that truly showcases the singer's voice. I Write Sins Not Tragedies is a lyrically out of place, but catchy as hell, track that swoops and swoons like any good pop-punk should. I Constantly Thank God for Esteban is admittedly a low point at this part of the album, but i have a large amount of affection for it. It attempts to soar, but finds itself falling flat <br /> <br />There's a Good Reason These Tables are Numbered, You Just Haven't Though of It Yet is my second favorite track on the album. It draws upon a type of jazz, and a breakup bitterness at a formal event. \\"I'm the new cancer, never lookeded better and you can't stand it, because you say so under your breath. You're reading lips when did he get all confident?\\" the singer spits at his ex, and it is very much believable. Great song. The final song has some noticeable differences. It is just as catchy, just as good, but takes part more in rock-pop than pop-punk. definitely a good sound for them.  <br /> <br />one last note about these guys. they have only been a band for about 6 months or so, and they are all 18 and 19. talent from people so young can either spell early flashes in the pan or musical legends in the making. lets hope for the latter. one way or another, this debut is going to be looked on with much affection from this fan
B000002KNY|5.0|I guess that sounds like a big statement but in my reality it is not too far from the truth. <br />Talking Heads enter the 80's with Fear of Music, arguably the most droll and cliched decade of rock. <br />Although there are plenty of shining lights of the 80's few can stake claim to have recorded an album that defined the era without having a dated sound which ties them to that time. <br />The sequence and flow of an album was never bettered by Talking Heads, and Eno's production while omnipresent is never overbearing. <br />Fear of Music IMHO is the most influential album of the last 25 years. <br />The effects are still manifesting themselves in current bands like Franz Ferdinand and Interpol. <br />Along with Joy Division and Wire, Talking Heads are really the beginning of the intellectualising of post punk, the ramifications which thankfully are still being felt today.
B0009I7O7A|5.0|I have to write a review in response to Raymond Lopez's review of this disc.<br />Ray I would agree with you that Enhanced Stereo is a load of rubbish and that putting out a disc with 16-bit 48hz audio is no different than a CD and a waste of the medium, but my friend this is not just an Enhanced Stereo release.<br />This disc also includes some very cool video footage, but the key elements are the audio.<br />Mr Lopez suggests that there is nothing Enhanced on this DualDisc - but people that is a GOOD THING.<br />Check this - Sony keeps putting out a number of discs with Enhanced Stereo on them.<br />CD = 16-bit 44.1hz audio<br />Enhanced Stereo = 16-bit 48Hz stereo<br />There's hardly any difference there at all - it's a complete sham.<br />Now onto DualDisc titles like Nine Inch Nails' \\"With Teeth\\" and \\"The Downward Spiral\\" or Dire Straits \\"Brothers In Arms.\\" These discs are all released with Advanced Resolution 5.1 surround tracks on them that are stunning. They blow Enhanced Stereo away.<br />Again<br />CD = 16-bit 44.1Hz audio<br />Enhanced Stereo = 16-bit 48Hz stereo<br />John Mayer RFS Dual Disc = Dolby Digital 5.1 multichannel audio.<br />NIN - Downward Spiral DualDisc = 24-bit 48Hz 5.1 multichannel audio<br /><br />Please for anyone else wondering if this disc is worth it - if you have a home theatre system and a DVD-Video player, or better yet have a DVD-Audio or SACD player, then check out some of the DualDisc titles, but look at what's on the disc. Enhanced Stereo is a load of rubbish, Advanced Resolution DVD-Audio (like the kind found on many DualDisc titles) is not rubbish and takes audio appreciation to the next level.<br /><br />EDIT - please note this disc has Dolby Digital 5.1 which can be played through a DVD-Video player. It DOES NOT have advanced resolution DVD-Audio on it. The best quality version of this release is the SACD version.
B00005JO1Y|5.0|Just like Peter Jackson, I have been enthralled with the story of Kong ever since I saw the original replayed one Saturday afternoon when I was probably no more than 10.  Lucky for me the same channel played Mighty Joe Young the very next week and I have been hooked ever since.  I am also one of the proud few who also enjoyed the 1976 Kong re-make with Jeff Bridges.  Sure it was cheesy, but it was Kong and I enjoyed it immensely.  Imagine my surprise when I found that the architect of the incredibly entertaining Lord of the Rings movies was planning on doing his own faithful rendition of Kong.<br /><br />First off, as an avid fan of special effects, I am just about the worst critic when it comes to paying such close attention to how realistic they are or aren't.  I have good and bad to say in regards to this edition of Kong: Overall the effects were stunning...however about the ONLY place where effects looked poor happened during the dinosaur stampede scene.  Absolutely gigantic creatures running towards you through a rather narrow ravine sounds a lot better than it turned out.  Was it a blast to watch anyway?  You bet.  Without a doubt, the Kong/T-Rex fight rivals just about any action scenes in virtually any film ever released.  Not just one, but Kong takes on 3 at the SAME TIME...all while cradling Ann Darrow in one hand.  Talk about an unfair fight.  Watching two of them get caught up in the enormous vines in a canyon wall STILL attempting to capture Ann was just incredible to say the least.  That scene alone ought to earn the movie the Academy Award for special effects.<br /><br />I would have to say that each scene featuring Kong looked authentic in every way.  Props to the folks who are out to give Industrial Light & Magic a run for the money as Hollywoods premiere special effects producers.  Certain portions of the film seemed to last just slightly longer than necessary.  I can't put my finger on exactly why, but even shaving off a couple of seconds would have made a huge difference.  I believe that Peter Jackson was so intent on doing such a good job that he almost lost sight of one of the biggest rules of movie making: leave us wanting MORE.  Don't get me wrong, I really REALLY enjoyed the movie...I would have liked CERTAIN scenes to have been cut by only a few seconds.<br /><br />Jackson brought a wonderful sense of entertainment specifically towards the end of the movie after Kong escapes into New York with Ann and finds his way into Central Park on a frozen pond.  This part of the movie was just spectacular.  Not just for how carefree it was, but how it allowed us to seriously CARE for the giant ape.  Unlike some of the scenes which lasted a bit too long, this one in particular was done virtually to perfection ending just as you begin to warm up to the playful side of Kong.<br /><br />The climatic ending atop the Empire State Building is simply movie-making at its finest.  The stunning visuals of New York caught up in the middle of the Depression were just amazing.  It ALL looked SO REAL.  Once again, kudos to the effects crew for recreating one of the truly bitter-sweet moments of film history, improving in EVERY way upon the original.  You KNOW what awaits Kong as he climbs to the peak of the worlds tallest building, but even as it was happening, I found myself rooting for Kong.  Every time the planes came by I was hoping against hope that he would catch and destroy them all.  Of course the ending came as no surprise, but all the same it did not stop me from hoping and wishing for things to have turned out differently.<br /><br />One tiny observation: am I the only person who noticed the incredible resemblance between Naomi Watts and Nicole Kidman?  There were several scenes that made Naomi look like Kidman's twin.  Oh well, even so, I just thought I'd bring it up.<br /><br />One small note for parents who are planning on bringing young ones: DON'T.  This movie is rated PG-13 for a very GOOD reason.  Not becauseof sexual themes, but because of quite disturbing visuals, namely the gigantic insects.  At the very least, shield them or take them out during this portion if you feel it necessary to bring them along.  It was quite intense, and could foster some disturbing dreams in the nights to come.<br /><br />All in all, Peter Jackson has cemented his place as Spielberg's rightful heir.  It has been a MIGHTY long time that Steven has stayed at the top of Hollywoods mountain of talented directors, and for good reason.  Who else could direct a movie featuring unknown actors with a script written by a 1st grader and earn a Hundred Million? But its time for someone new to take his place and I believe that person IS Peter Jackson.<br /><br />If you are looking for a three-hour getaway from the world, give King Kong a try and be prepared to be totally enthralled for a very long time.  I already want to see it again.on.  Not because of sexual themes, but because of quite disturbing visuals, namely the gigantic insects.  At the very least, shield them or take them out during this portion if you feel it necessary to bring them along.  It was quite intense, and could foster some disturbing dreams in the nights to come. <br /> <br />All in all, Peter Jackson has cemented his place as Spielberg's rightful heir.  It has been a MIGHTY long time that Steven has stayed at the top of Hollywoods mountain of talented directors, and for good reason.  Who else could direct a movie featuring unknown actors with a script written by a 1st grader and earn a Hundred Million? But its time for someone new to take his place and I believe that person IS Peter Jackson.   <br /> <br />If you are looking for a three-hour getaway from the world, give King Kong a try and be prepared to be totally enthralled for a very long time.  I already want to see it again.

If you are into pop culture, Gremlins is probably one of the many unique films of the 1980's, especially 1984. To sum up the story, a man gets his 18 year old son a pet from Chinatown known as a Mogwei (spelling?). The pet's name is Gizmo and there are a few rules to consider. The first, don't let it near bright light or sun light which could kill it. The second, don't let it get wet. The third, never feed it after midnight. Sound ridiculous? It is, but the movie is still good none the less. There is campy and somewhat demented humor here and there from the gremlins themselves even though they turn out to be semi-vicious monsters but the movie doesn't fail to entertain those with open minds. Plus, the character development along with the acting is good and you may find yourself wanting to watch Gremlins every couple years or so. Though the movie starts out serious its B-roots tend to show but that doesn't hurt it. The DVD has good features which is an improvement over the original DVD release.

B000BW7QWW|5.0|Translating a cult TV show to the big screen is often tricky business. Even with a heavyweight director like Robert Wise \\"Star Trek: The Motion Picture\\" did well at the box office critically the film became the Titanic with its long ponderous shots of V'Ger and the long lingering affectionate gaze at the Enterprise. Few TV properties truly make the jump to the big screen well so I was surprised and elated that \\"Serenity\\" Joss Whedon's (\\"Buffy The Vampire Slayer\\", \\"Angel\\") film extension of his TV show \\"Firefly\\" actually was very good. Fans of the show turned out in droves and critically it was a success but the theater seats were empty for most of its showings. That's too bad because Whedon does a nice job of giving a backstory to nonfans and still manages to capture the flavor of the TV show.<br /><br />Set centuries in the future the transport vessel Serenity commanded by Mal Reynolds (Nathan Fillion who comes the closest to channeling the spirit of Han Solo since Harrison Ford) is smuggling more than contraband-they're carrying a River Tam (Summer Glau) who has been altered by the government to become a brilliant killing machine and they want her back. Her brother Simon (Sean Maher) fakes his way into the facility where she's being kept and rescues her he spirits her off in the Serenity. The Alliance sends a nasty operative (Chiwetel Ejiofor) who will stop at nothing to obtain River including murdering anyone who stands in his way not just because of what she can do but also because of what she knows about illicit experiments the Alliance has been conducting since its formation. Mal bonded with Zoe (Gina Torres), her husband and pilot of the Serenity Walsh (Alan Tudyk), engineer Kaylee (Jewel Straite) and Jayne (Adam Baldwin) during the Brown Coat War for independence (Whedon was inspired to create the backstory for \\"Firefly\\" from the conflict during the Civil War and other incidents in U.S. history) Unfortunately, the pursuit of the Alliance puts the crew of Serenity at odds with River and Simon and they begin to wear out their welcome.<br /><br />Featuring a stellar cast, \\"Serenity\\" is a rarity in that it makes the transition to the big screen effortlessly and Whedon manages to clue in those who didn't follow the series with a breathtaking opening sequence that illustrates things fans were told had occurred during the first season but never saw. I suppose \\"Firefly\\" fans can satisfy themselves with the fact that they got their movie which essentially crams the story arc Whedon had planned for the second season into a two hour feature film. Sadly, the film stiffed at the box office despite a terrific campaign by Universal to attract both the hardcore Brown coat audience (so called because of the colors Mal's troops wore during the Civil War with the Alliance). It's unlikely we'll see another \\"Firefly\\" TV show or movie. Since Whedon wraps things up but also leaves the door open the film manages to work both ways for fans by providing closure to one of the main story points of the first season and opening up possibilities (which no doubt will continue in novels and comic books) for further adventures. \\"Serenity\\" manages to be that rare thing in science fiction films; a kick-ass adventure with some thought behind it. While some of the plot points that are revealed in \\"Serenity\\" are a bit predictable the film manages to combine the best elements of space opera and science fiction to create valentine for fans of the show.<br /><br />\\"Serenity\\" looks extremely good on this DVD with the original theatrical presentation of the film well represented. The colors are vivid and bright where appropriate and the clarity of the image exceedingly good. The one area that this transfer could improve is to eliminate the edge enhancement that appears in some of the high contrast sequence action sequences shot for the film. The 5.1 Dolby Digital presentation of the film nicely captures the active soundtrack from the theatrical exhibit of the film. Dialogue comes across crisp and clear while action sequences don't have the compressed muddy sound that I've seen in some recent releases.<br /><br />While the film looks and sounds very good, the extras leave a lot to be desired which makes me suspect Universal will be re-releasing this in a double dip edition later next year. I don't have news but I suspect the sales of this set will determine if an enhanced edition comes out next year (or perhaps Universal is holding that for the Blu-Ray edition that is no doubt in preparation for next year). We get three featurettes on the series the best of which \\"Future History: The Story of Earth That Was\\" clocks in at around 5 minutes. Whedon talks to the camera here explaining how he came up with the concept for the show. \\"What's in a Firefly\\" focuses on the optical effects with Whedon and members of the visual effects team discussing how they conceived some of the best visual sequences. \\"Relighting the Firefly\\" is the longest of the three at about 10 minutes and covers the resurrection of the show from the graveyard of cancelled TV shows. ***CAUTION THERE IS A SPOILER AHEAD ABOUT THE CONCLUSION OF THE FILM AHEAD. SKIP TO THE NEXT PARAGRAPH IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE FILM***While each featurette is of solid quality Universal should and could have done a separately disc of extras covering everything from what made it into the movie that was planned for the non-existent second season to Whedon's controversial decision to eliminate some of the major cast members for this film.<br /><br />Whedon's chatty commentary definitely ranks as the highlight of the extras included for me. The discussion of his thought process behind the film's plot and how he tied in various points from the series was refreshingly frank and fascinating to listen to. Whedon's impish sense of humor also gets a nice airing in his discussion on making the film.<br /><br />While the fact that this is truly the end of the \\"Firefly\\" saga will be a bitter pill for fans to swallow, Whedon delivers a truly stunning valentine with \\"Serenity\\" channeling the major plot points for a planned second season that never materialized. The image quality and transfer of \\"Serenity\\" is quite good but the extras a bit disappointing particularly compared to many lesser films that receive a DVD release. Whedon's commentary remains a highlight of this set. Definitely worth buying if you're a fan of the series although I'd suggest nonfans who haven't seen the TV show might want to rent some of the first season DVD boxed set to get a sense of the flavor of the show before buying.ross crisp and clear while action sequences don't have the compressed muddy sound that I've seen in some recent releases. B000002BQK|5.0|People who tend to judge and criticise the music of Mariah do so based on the few singles they have heard rather than an indepth exporation of her key albulm tracks, many of which never got commercial release.  Butterfly marked a watershed in the career of Mariah; a fusion of urban beats and soulful ballads which continued  the direction  she had started to take in Daydream  with 'Fantasy' and wanted to follow up musically. Those only familiar with mariahs higger register will be suprised to find this albulm is a study in vocal restraint; the vocals croon over slick  beats and meander with the music to create sublime songs delivered with passion and heartfelt honesty.  <br />
B00007LTIB|5.0|Released in 1974, this would be the last studio album from Yes for at least three years until the debut of their triumphant 1977 album Going for the One.  Structurally, Relayer duplicates the format of Close to the Edge (1972) and as such is comprised of three pieces including the 21'55 epic The Gates of Delirium (it was Tolstoy's tome \\"War and Peace\\" that inspired vocalist Jon Anderson to put this epic together), in addition to the comparatively shorter pieces Sound Chaser (9'25\\") and To be Over (9'08\\").  In contrast with Tales from Topographic Oceans (1973), the energy levels are completely over the top on Relayer and may reflect the enthusiasm of new (Swiss) keyboardist Patrick Moraz.  I think its worth noting that Moraz was a first chair player and his contributions to Relayer are consistently brilliant throughout - as an exceptional talent with a unique playing style, it is unfortunate he was not with Yes for a longer period of time.<br /><br />Although the frenetic pace of Sound Chaser is exhilarating and the comparatively dreamy To be Over is a wonderful piece (Steve Howe's favorite apparently), The Gates of Delirium is my own personal favorite.  Would I be way off the mark to say that The Gates of Delirium is the most well constructed large-scale composition in all of progressive rock?  Being a huge Yes fan, it would be impossible to remain objective, but then again I have listened to a lot of prog and this composition really stands out.  Over a period of 15 minutes or so, this multi-movement suite gradually develops into a wildly churning sonic maelstrom, with the sounds of shattering glass and the clangorous racket of metal on metal (they collected parts from the junkyard to create this effect) swirling around and fighting with violent and white-hot synthesizer lines, Squires thundering bass parts, and Steve Howe's absolutely manic guitar playing.  Just when it appears that the CD player might actually erupt in flames (or wrench itself loose from its moorings), the chaos gradually dissipates into soft, muted textures, which then give way to the beautiful and gentle closing movement \\"Soon\\".  Soon is a deeply emotional piece of music and Trevor Horn (he provided vocals on the Drama album 1980) has been quoted as saying that it \\"brought him to tears\\".  This piece was eventually abstracted from the larger composition and issued as a single, which has been included on this remastered disc along with a studio run-through of The Gates of Delirium and a single edit of Sound Chaser.  As somebody who once owned this on vinyl, the bonus tracks do not really enhance my enjoyment of the album although they are OK.<br /><br />The musicianship on this album is mind-numbingly virtuosic and as I have mentioned, Patrick Moraz is outstanding.  Even Alan White (Bill Bruford once condescendingly referred to him as a good \\"rock\\" drummer) provides some great drumming on Relayer, especially on Sound Chaser and it is probably his best recorded performance.  Chris Squire once again demonstrates what it means to be a world class bassist and presents bass parts that range from the subtle to the impossibly difficult, while Steve Howe plays like a man possessed, with scalar runs played at breakneck speeds.  OK I need to slow down - just thinking about this album makes me completely hyper.<br /><br />The remastering on Relayer is wonderful and the CD package comes with a great set of detailed liner notes and color photos - the information may be \\"old hat\\" for hardcore Yes fans but should ultimately prove of interest to most.  This is the real McCoy folks - progressive rock in all of its splendor.  Highly recommended along with all Yes albums released between 1971 (The Yes Album) and 1977 (Going for the One).ngs), the chaos gradually dissipates into soft, muted textures, which then give way to the beautiful and gentle closing movement \\"Soon\\".  Soon is a deeply emotional piece of music and Trevor Horn (he provided vocals on the Drama album 1980) has been quoted as saying that it \\"brought him to tears\\".  This piece was eventually abstracted from the larger composition and issued as a single, which has been included on this remastered disc along with a studio run-through of The Gates of Delirium and a single edit of Sound Chaser.  As somebody who once owned this on vinyl, the bonus tracks do not really enhance my enjoyment of the album although they are OK.<br /><br />The musicianship on this album is mind-numbingly virtuosic and as I have mentioned, Patrick Moraz is outstanding.  Even Alan White (Bill Bruford once condescendingly referred to him as a good \\"rock\\" drummer) provides some great drumming on Relayer, especially on Sound Chaser and it is probably his best recorded performance.  Chris Squire once again demonstrates what it means to be a world class bassist and presents bass parts that range from the subtle to the impossibly difficult, while Steve Howe plays like a man possessed, with scalar runs played at breakneck speeds.  OK I need to slow down - just thinking about this album makes me completely hyper.<br /><br />The remastering on Relayer is wonderful and the CD package comes with a great set of detailed liner notes and color photos - the information may be \\"old hat\\" for hardcore Yes fans but should ultimately prove of interest to most.  This is the real McCoy folks - progressive rock in all of its splendor.  Highly recommended along with all Yes albums released between 1971 (The Yes Album) and 1977 (Going for the One).
B00005JO1Y|5.0|I am capable of liking and admiring movies of all shapes and sizes.  My favorites this year include CAPOTE and CRASH.  But sometimes nothing fits the bill for movie thrills better than an outstanding, outsized epic.  The kind of movie where you simply MUST see it on the large screen, with a large crowd.  This year, the \\"epic\\" films have been pretty disappointing.  Even crowd-pleasers like the third STAR WARS installment and WAR OF THE WORLDS mostly pleased at a surface level.  Others, like STEALTH, didn't please at all! <br /> <br />KING KONG is satisfying on an emotional level.  It satisfies on a visceral, action-loving, special-effects level.  It pleases those who appreciate good acting and directing.  It simply WORKS. <br /> <br />I'm dismayed at anyone who says the film is too long.  What the heck is wrong with sitting for three hours through something that is this rich, textured and exciting?  True, if it is three hours of boredom, you can get quite fidgety...but then again, 90 minutes of garbage will make me fidget too.  But if I've been immersed in a world so thoroughly conceived and presented, populuated by people who are interesting to know and engaged in a plot that is told in a gut-wrenching way...the movie seems short.  I won't say, \\"I didn't want it to end,\\" because in actuality, the film has a rich beginning, a thrilling middle and an emotionally wrenching end.  I had been taken through a complete story, and I didn't need more.  It was just right. <br /> <br />I won't run down the plot.  But I will touch on some key elements.  First of all, the special effects are special. I was most blown away by the loving detail lavished on recreating depression-era New York City.  In the opening scenes, and in the big finale, NYC is beautifully rendered...I doubt we'll see it so loving done again.  It's a city on the brink of a collision between massive progress and massive poverty.  The new and shiny versus the old and decrepit.  Technology against a giant beast.<br /> <br />The action sequences are like nothing you've seen before.  There's a protracted sequence when Kong battles three velocoraptor-like beings while trying to keep Naomi Watts alive.  It is breathtaking..in the best way...it makes you hold your breath.  Later, the sequence a top the Empire State Building is damn near perfect.  It feels so cold, lonely and primal up there, and Peter Jackson films everything from angles that quite literally leave you dizzy.  A couple of scenes were still a bit rough, though, to be fair.  The scene in which the explorers all flee from underneath the giant legs of a stampeding brontosauruses doesn't quite convince.  It shows it's green-screen seams.  But overall, this is some of the best stuff ever.  Kong himself is simply great...totally convincing. <br /> <br />Jack Black is well cast in a part that isn't as much against type as some would claim.  A driven, unethical ego-maniac.  That's not such a stretch, is it?  Adrien Brody is quite nuanced in his role...which was smaller than I thought it would be, but well done.  Kyle Chandler has a smallish role as the \\"star\\" of Black's new film, and he's really funny.  But it is Naomi Watts' show...every scene she plays is done with whole-hearted conviction.  Her interactions with Kong make you forget totally that he was NOT in these scenes with her.  It all feels completely authentic...which for such an outrageous story is pretty amazing.  She feels like an \\"old-time\\" star...all modern mannerisms, all modern irony are gone.   <br /> <br />Also, the scene on a frozen pond in Central Park is brilliant.  If you have a dry eye during that one (or God-forbid, during the final scene between Watts and Kong) I do feel bad for you. <br /> <br />Yes, the film requires an attention-span.  But it rewards with so many riches.  It is not a film for little kids, not because of the action, but probably because of the time it takes getting there.  I saw a lot of restless 8 or 9 year olds in the theater.  But I saw a lot of 13 year olds (including my own) totally enthralled.  And I even caught myself literally on the edge of my seat.  I NEVER do that...I'm far to \\"cool\\" to get that caught up in a film...but the epic KONG made me feel like a kid at his first movie again.  Thanks, Peter Jackson, for that feeling.

B00005JO1Y|5.0|Academy Award winning director Peter Jackson (the Lord Of The Rings trilogy) joins Academy Award winning actor Adrian Brody, Academy Award nominee Naomi Watts, and comedian Jack Black in the heart winning remake of the classic tale of King Kong.  <br /> <br />The movie pursues an eccentric 1930's film maker, Black, who takes off on an ocean voyage after getting scolded by his producers following a bad test screening to find the mysterious Skull Island where it was said is home to a monstrous creature. All that the director wants is to capture scenes from this island to put in his next movie to make millions. Accompanying him is an aspiring actress named Ann, played brilliantly by Watts, his writer, played by Brody, and the rest of the movie and ship crew.  <br /> <br />Cutting to the chase, King Kong, an enormous ape, is discovered on the Island occupied by grizzly natives who sacrifice Ann to him. What occurs between Ann and the ape is a heartwarming relationship. Ann discovers that the monstrous animal is not that monstrous, but playful, courageous and loyal. The scenes where Kong rescues Ann from the raging dinosaurs, including a few T-rexes, are reminiscent to Jurassic Park, but amazing action sequences that end with quite a laugh.  <br /> <br />The story evolves into a striking love story, not a romance, between the ape and Ann that end up in an incredibly rebuilt 1930's New York City, where Kong causes awe and havoc in the city, but all for the search of his lovely Ann where he sees a beauty that kills the beast within him. <br /> <br />It's a lovely tale, and you will feel pleased to watch it despite many criticisms revolving around differences between the original and this new version.  <br /> <br />King Kong will make you laugh, cry, and sit at the edge of your seat. Definitely one of the best movie experiences of the year! <br /> <br />Recommended <br /> <br />A-

B00009RAJI|5.0|Ah, the '70's.  They are but a distant blur in my memory.  Back then, in the summer that this album came out, we were listening to Hotel California, Frampton Comes Alive, and Rumours.  We'd play them so much, we'd have to put a penny on the needle of the record player. Mac wisely decided to include it here smack dab in the middle of the cd, where it certainly belonged all the time. One drawback though is that this version of \\"Silver Springs\\" is not the same version that was on the flip side of \\"Go Your Own Way\\": I would have preferred the original version.    Today, I find myself listening more to the bonus CD than the original, because some of the rough tracks and demos are just so darn good.  The Gold Dust Woman demo, in my humble opinion, is worth the price of the CD.  It's an acoustic, stripped down version that's just totally nailed by the band.  Another good demo that's better than the final cut is \\"Think About It\\", a song that Stevie Nicks put on her first solo LP-  this version is simply better.  The bonus track cd ends with a nice little jam session that rounds out the disc nicely. I do return to disc one regularly so I can listen to \\"The Chain\\", and \\"I Don't Want to Know\\", two of my personal favs.       Overall, this disc is a better choice for the fan, who, like me, grew up listening to this album.  You definitely get your money's worth here, as well as a look into how the band refined their music.  This was the biggest album of the '70's and for good reason. It still brings a smile to my face after all these years.

Though very primitive special effects were available at the time, one cannot help admire the excellent screenplay.<br /><br />The 1976 remake should be trashed. Just terrible in every sense. Only good thing about the film is Jessica Lange. Kong looks like a guy in a costume, especially the way he walks upright like a human being.<br /><br />Peter Jackson's 2005 remake is excellent, but not perfect. The film captures depression era New York very well. The CGI is a marvel, Kong looks very real. The highlights for me were: the way Kong and Ann related, a re-telling of Beauty and the Beast; the way he tenderly held and touched her; how she slept nestled on his arm; the Central Park scene where Kong was slipping on the ice, NOT skating...a stroke of genius; and the climax atop the Empire State Building. What could have been toned down was the amount of prehistoric creatures (a little goes a long way). The insect scene added nothing to the film, and should have been cut. Finally, the battles between Kong and the prehistoric creatures, though impressive and thrilling, really moved way too fast for the eye and brain to focus on and capture. This seems to be a trend in Hollywood these days. Directors, please S-L-O-W  down the action scenes a wee bit so the audience can actually enjoy what they're watching. Recommended popcorn movie.

0393327655|3.0|Ever see the Mosquito Coast?   There was this broccoli farmer who hired a genius, Allie Fox, to help him harvest his crops better.  Allie did him one better and built a refrigerator.  The farmer was frustrated that Allie didn't do what he was asked to do:  make a machine that speeds the harvest. <br />Allie was frustrated with the lack of understanding in society and wanted to strike out on his own (in the jungles of Central America) and build a new, perfect society.   <br /> <br />When the farmer found out that that was happening, here's what he said to Allie's son (played by the late River Phoenix):   <br /> <br />\\"You're father is the worst kind of pain in the neck:  He's a know-it-all whose sometimes right.  He's a very dangerous man.  You tell him that, Charlie.  He's a very dangerous man.\\"    <br /> <br />The old farmer proves to be right..   <br /> <br />The family ultimately is driven to ruin because Allie would rather be delusional than compromise his thesis on life.  I always related well to Allie Fox..    <br />and I see the danger of being like him.   <br /> <br />Sam Harris faces this danger, I think.  His book, \\"End of Faith\\" most likely came to him in a flash following 9-11 and he hammered it out in a fevered pitch until it was published.    <br />It reads with razor sharp clarity with ever \\"i\\" dotted and every \\"t\\" crossed.  I know.  I'm an atheist and have thought these things through for many years.    <br /> <br />His thesis is well crafted and covers all the tedium that is required to build a bullet-proof case.    <br /> <br />So, what's wrong with the thesis?   <br /> <br />He gives his fear of the the irrationality of religous people for more credence than any belief that other motives for the terrorism we are seeing today could be controlling their behavior. <br /> <br />While he is technically correct with all arguments,  the thesis is more a complete painting, than a derivation of a true thesis.   <br />Harris paints the picture he sees.   <br />In that picture,  faith is the killer of civilization.    <br />Moderate or fundamental.. it leads to the end of us all.. unless you profess Jainism or Budhism which are live-and-let-live religions.    <br />The painting includes the ills of Christian past, and they are many (and I suspect there will be more).   <br />It includes the ills of Muslim terrorism including a refutation that terrorism is economically or educationally based.   <br />He cites examples of very educated and mainstream people, as the ones in England, getting involved in bombings.    <br />The painting washes over the arguments of Chomsky and the like that the Muslim response is a reaction to US policy. <br />   <br />In fact,  he boldly states that the US has moved beyond its odius stage (as demonstrated in the Mai Lai massacre in 1968) to being a well-meaning giant.    <br />The people that carried out those atrocities are still alive.    <br />I don't know how much time has to pass to \\"be past\\" something,  but on the Harris time scale,  Osama still has a chance at redemption. <br /> <br />Why don't I like the painting that Harris makes?    <br />Because he ignores two things:    <br />1) for lack of better word, the \\"human spirit\\".    <br />2) any acknowledgement of how the methodical use of political might might be interpreted by those on the receiving end.   <br /> <br />He paints pictures of all the evil despots of the past and makes black-and-white examples of how they'd wield power compared to the way we well-meaning-giant Americans do.    <br />Since it's hard to tell when the salt is missing from the soup, let me add it here:    <br />He makes a point in one of his scenarios that if we had a weapon that could commit no colleratal damage and gave it to US leaders, Osama, and Hussein,  the use of that weapon would find much more use by the Muslims (or Hitler or Stalin). <br /> <br />So, let's extend the model to more American leaders, since we can't be comparing anyone currently inpower with Hitler, Stalin, or Osama:    <br />What would FDR do?   <br />What would Truman do?   <br />What would Kennedy do?   <br />What would Johnson, Nixon, Carter, or Reagan do?     <br />Let's see:   Tokyo (burned to the ground),  Hiroshima,  Nagaski,   South Vietnam, North Vietnam, Cuba, East Timor, Panama, Haiti, Greneda, and Nicaragua.   <br />What was it that Nixon said?  Kill everything that moves?    <br />We haven't moved on...   and we should always be very wary of applying the force of the well-meaning-giant.   <br />Perhaps we should limit it to cases where we are asked (by the victims).   <br /> <br />And for the human spirit?   <br />I think the picture he paints of the Muslim world is highly technical and extremely unfair.    <br />We are all human and capable of despicable actions as has been demonstrated.    <br />But, perhaps there is a more rich explanation of the \\"mad\\" suicide bombings than 72 virgins bathing in milk and honey (or whatever it is). <br />I personally would not die for that purpose, but there are purposes for which I would die:   <br />to protect my family or even my community...    <br />it would be a personal choice in personal defense.   Maybe this sort of motivation is playing a role with the Muslims. <br /> <br />This is different that the crimes of Christian past in that they were instituted by state power on weak people.    <br />In the Muslim case, it is weak people exacting the only force they have on strong people.   <br />I see no mention of this in the picture that Harris has painted and it is a very important distinction.    <br />Worse,  his picture incites fear among us which, as he well understands,  is a belief that could lead to action...  action based on a belief he created..  perhaps a faith.    <br />So he bears responsibility for motivating action that I would see as ill-founded and regrettable.    <br /> <br />... back to human spirit:    <br />Perhaps the suicide bombers see the US, because of its policies and actions, as a threat to their way of life IN THEIR OWN COUNTRIES.    <br />Notice, there are no Arab bases in the US.   <br />There are no SOFA's (status of forces agreements).   <br />No one from an Arab nation is demanding regime change over here.    <br />We however,  are doing all of that.   <br />Maybe we mean well.    <br />But does it matter? <br /> <br />I mean well when I tell my wife that she needs to work out more.   <br />I assure you,  it doesn't help.  At all.    <br />Perhaps the educated people who are motivated to act are not acting on a mission from Allah as much as they are acting as a response to a sense of urgent threat to the survival of their way of life.   <br />Perhaps the rise of fundamentalism in Muslim countries has many sources:  the enormous class division perpetrated by the ruling class over everyone else.  The extreme poverty and lack of hope of the poor.   <br />People want answers.   Clerics provide them.   And so it is here.   <br />Again, we are painting pictures,  not deriving ultimate truths.    <br />We all look and interpret.   <br />For me, and I think many,  a moral life is one in which we encumber each other only to the extent that is necessary for the group to live.   <br />That is,  we mind our own business as much as possible, but when your business involves me, then I should play some role in those decisions.    <br /> <br />There will always be the odd nut that wants to kill people because some \\"mandate\\", but as long as he or she has no far-reaching power,  it's irrelevant.   <br />One crime and the problem is contained. <br /> <br />The \\"well-meaning-monster\\" has been tried before.   <br />It turns into a regular monster all too easily, so perhaps it's best to just not be monsters and let people be..    <br />  <br />and maybe we'll get along better than Harris fears.

0743454537|5.0|This is the first Jodi Picoult book I ever read.  I had always considered her to be a \\"women's lit\\" writer, and had never paid much attention to her novels.  Was I wrong or what?  I was immediately taken with the premise of the novel: a 13 year old girl wants to be medically emancipated from her parents because she feels she doesn't have any say in being a \\"guinea pig\\" or \\"spare parts\\" for her terminally ill sister dying of leukemia.  I have to admit it was a hard read at first as Ms. Picoult wrote each chapter from the POV of a different character.  However, once you got into the book and story, I could not put the book down.  Since the book has been out for a long time and a lot of people have read it, I don't feel bad about giving away the ending.  I say to the other readers/reviewers here on Amazon: real life doesn't always work out the way you want it.  If you are expecting a feel-good, isn't-life-wonderful, wasn't-that-a-miracle? ending, don't bother.  The ending will devastate you.  As another famous writer once said, \\"I don't write the story; the story writes itself.\\"  In reality, the dying sister would probably not have lived as long as she has.  I don't see the ending as a \\"yank the rug out from under you\\" literary trick.  I see this book as the ultimate example of irony.  It should be taught in high school English classes as such.  It makes the traditional stories to represent irony like O. Henry's \\"Gift of the Magi\\" pale by comparison.  Although I too was shocked and disappointed, I respect Ms. Picoult for keeping it real.  Looking back, I can see no other ending; the story writes itself.  In real life, people you care about die. Characters you have come to care about die.  For all our medical advancements, adults and children with leukemia die.  Donors die tragic deaths in traffic accidents.  The ending of this book has left a lasting impression on me; don't take life for granted.  Enjoy what you have while you're here.  If you are looking for a book toread passively and not be affected by its messages or themes, this is NOT the one to read.  Read something by Jane Green or Nora Roberts.  If you want a book with some deep ethical and philosophical issues to wrestle, pick this up.  But don't say you haven't been warned. You may not like how the story turns out, but I guarantee you: YOU WILL NEVER FORGET IT.  (No matter how much you'd like to).
B000AGTPUU|1.0|My girlfriend wanted to see this.  I had doubts.     I had read the book--if \\"read\\" is the right word for a book with no plot.  It was pretty and aimless, and I wondered how they could make a movie out of it.    They did it by stuffing it with miles of howling rollercoaster scenes, some not-very-magic magic characters, and more howling rollercoaster scenes.    Half the characters are voiced by Tom Hanks; the other half are voiced by Tom Hanks talking through a handkerchief.    A boatload of money was spent on this.  The computer animation is dazzling and whizbang--but never ceases to be dull.    The main reason for the dullness is the lack of charm of the characters.  They are often sentimental, but never truly warm.  And the computer-animation gives them a waxy, corpse-like look.    They all look like underdone refugees from a Tim Burton movie.    I wondered if children might like it, so I asked a friend who teaches 5-year-olds.  She had read them the book, which they liked, and asked those who had seen the movie if they like that too.  They didn't.  They said it was dull.    Christmas turkey.
0385335482|4.0|Becky Bloomwood has left home in order to share a flat in London with her friend, and to write for the magazine \\"Successful Saving\\".  The irony is that rather than do any saving herself, Becky chooses to spend her small paycheck--and then some!  When letters from her creditors begin to get nasty, Becky hides them and, in order to make herself feel better, she goes on another shopping trip.  She imagines all sorts of ways to become rich enough to pay off her debts--from winning the lottery to marrying a wealthy man.  None of her schemes seem to work, however, and she finds herself deeper and deeper in debt.  This is an amusing book whose main character is recognizable to anyone who is a shopaholic or who has a friend who falls in that category.  Nothing deep here, but it is a fun read.

B00004BZ16|5.0|I just finished reading Harold Pinter's Nobel Lecture \\"Art, Truth & Politics\\". It is easy to see why he won the 2005 Nobel Prize for Literature. But while reading what he said about Nicaragua in the 80s, the Contras and Sandinistas, reminded me of being 19 or so when this album came out.<br /><br />As a US citizen living in a fairly Reagan-loving state (Arizona) and having been told that the Contras were the good guys, I couldn't quite figure out why this band would be for the other team. But such was the beginning of my political enlightenment. The Clash and other punk and alternative bands were the first messiahs of political truth for me in my little sheltered life.<br /><br />Now there are Rap albums and Hip-Hop albums today that are important and political like The Clash's were then, but except for the few songs that make the list for Top 40 radio...for listeners who are no longer educated enough to get the irony--those more radical songs are mostly shared between friends and played late at night on College-Indy stations.<br /><br />In Milan Kundera's book, \\"The Incredible Lightness of Being\\" The author reflects on Nietzsche's idea of Eternal Return, and the moral consequences we face by not living in a world where all things are repeated ad infinitum. He writes,<br /><br />\\"Not long ago, I caught myself experiencing a most<br /><br />incredible sensation. Leafing through a book on<br /><br />Hitler, I was touched by some portraits: they reminded<br /><br />me of my childhood. I grew up during the war; several<br /><br />members of my family perished in Hitler's<br /><br />concentration camps; but what were their deaths<br /><br />compared with the memories of a lost period in my<br /><br />life, a period that would never return?<br /><br />This reconciliation with Hitler reveals the profound<br /><br />moral perversity of a world that rests essentially on<br /><br />the nonexistence of return, for in this world<br /><br />everything is pardoned in advance and therefore<br /><br />cynically permitted.\\"<br /><br />I remembered that passage today as I read Pinter's speech, as well as this album by The Clash. Because there was a bittersweetness to the memory of these songs, but tinged with the idea that the truth is that there is perhaps an Eternal Return of the same, and thus something even more deeply, impossibly immoral about the fact that some 25 years later, we are still playing the part of Imperialist bullies, murderers and exploiters--more than ever--dispatching a hideous form of terror under the banner of democracy everywhere on our little globe. So maybe now that the truth is so intolerable, it will finally be powerful enough to bring action. And people will be held accountable? I hope so.<br /><br />Harold Pinter's speech is brilliant and can easily be found in a search on the web, or on the Nobel Prize site. I'm sure I will get many \\"not helpful\\" votes for this, but I hope that at least one person will take the time to read Pinter's words since mine are admittedly inarticulate and inadequate to the task.\\" <br /> <br />I remembered that passage today as I read Pinter's speech, as well as this album by The Clash. Because there was a bittersweetness to the memory of these songs, but tinged with the idea that the truth is that there is perhaps an Eternal Return of the same, and thus something even more deeply, impossibly immoral about the fact that some 25 years later, we are still playing the part of Imperialist bullies, murderers and exploiters--more than ever--dispatching a hideous form of terror under the banner of democracy everywhere on our little globe. So maybe now that the truth is so intolerable, it will finally be powerful enough to bring action. And people will be held accountable? I hope so. <br /> <br />Harold Pinter's speech is brilliant and can easily be found in a search on the web, or on the Nobel Prize site. I'm sure I will get many \\"not helpful\\" votes for this, but I hope that at least one person will take the time to read Pinter's words since mine are admittedly inarticulate and inadequate to the task.

B000B8QEZG|4.0|Sometimes I wonder what I would do without MTV.  I was able to stream the entire Confessions album before its release on The Leak at MTV.com; so, if this review is early, (1) you'll know why and (2) that it's legit.<br /><br />I really like Madonna.  My fondest memories of her are from the late 90s, when after the Sex book and Erotica album, she came out with Bedtime Stories... which completely blew me away and made me forgive her for all the crap she'd given us in the name of pushing the envelope.  (Not to say that I don't appreciate the evolution process.  Fortunately, I can see the artistic value in a lot of what was made during the Erotica years.)  Nevertheless, Bedtime Stories and then Ray of Light made me love Madonna just as I had growing up with Like A Virgin.  Only this time, she seemed smarted, more relevant, truer... grown up.  And she was.  Ray of Light will always be my favorite Madonna album... because I too felt \\"like I just got home.\\"  Those lyrics still resonate with me.<br /><br />I've never been more excited about an album as I am with the release of Confessions... especially after American Life, which I wasn't too keen on.  (The production value could have been so much more.  But the Love Profusion remixes were really outstanding.)<br /><br />Anyway here's my blow-by-blow of the new album:<br /><br />Hung Up - By now you've all heard it... unless of course you're living under a rock.  And for that reason I'm not going to go into detail.  I wouldn't necessarily say this track is indicative of the rest of the album.<br /><br />Get Together - I almost fell over when I heard this.  It's amazing from beginning to end.  It's a heavy synth track with really cool, smooth vocals that seem to layer on top of each other; it gives the song a lot more depth during the chorus and sounds really good.  And the beat is simply incredible, a bit Stardust inspired (Music Sounds Better With You).  This is a whimsical, airy, and very sexy track.  And I'm not sure what the musical term for it is, but it's got a great build up, and in that sense, reminds me a bit of Hyperballad by Bjork.<br /><br />Sorry - They say this is going to be the second release off the album.  I hope so; it'll be a great radio-play dance song.  It's got a sort of a Jackson 5 thump-thump that's especially apparent at the beginning of the song.  I think it has a hard time getting off the ground though after following Get Together on the track listing.  But half-way through it, you realize, \\"Hey, this is pretty sharp.\\"  The chorus is extremely catchy; so, beware earworms.<br /><br />Future Lovers - A Donna Summer inspired track a la \\"I Feel Love.\\"  I Googled the chorus; apparently she's saying, \\"Give me evidence of its brilliance.\\"  I like this one; it's fun to dance to, but it's obviously a b-side and, unfortunately for some of us, this will never see the light of day (get airplay).  ...A great bridge to the next song nonetheless.<br /><br />I Love New York - This is the most rock-sounding song on the album.  Unfortunately, the lyrics suck.  This could have been a really great track and possibly something for radio play.  (The music lends itself to that well.)  I dunno.  It's fun and cheesy... something I would expect from ole Britney Spears.  But it's an appropriate end to what I would call the first act of the album.  There's an obvious downturn as this song leads into the next two tracks.<br /><br />Let It Will Be - Ahhh.  The 80s.  (Don't mind the strings.  Wait until it picks up; you'll get it.)<br /><br />Forbidden Love - Okay.  I absolutely HATED this song when I first heard it.  But listening to it in the context of the whole album on those days in rush hour traffic actually didn't kill me, make me want run someone over, or throw my radio out the window.  Granted, the song starts out overly dramatic.  Oh, Madonna!  Then comes the Daft Punk style chorus followed by a nice little thump thump that actually sound a lot like an old Kylie song.  It stillsounds a little downtempo but redeems itself in the chorus.  LOVE the chorus!  It just makes you wanna wave your hands in the air like some old queen on the dancefloor.  The \\"praise Jesus\\" stance.  Love this song... this block of songs actually because the next track is AMAZING!<br /><br />Jump - Put your dancing shoes on girl!  You're gonna love this song.  I'll be very surprised if it's not released as a single.  I love what she's singing about; it's got a positive message and a great 70s beat.  Love the high-hat!  Let's go dancing ya'll!<br /><br />How High - I would say this is the most Kylie-sounding track on the album.  And it reminds me a bit of \\"Come Into My World\\" from the Fever album.  (Not lyrically of course.)  I like the lyrics though.  I know they're about what she goes through and has gone through in life, but I think a lot of us can relate in our own ways to the personal and professional life choices she sings about.  Though it's a downtempo and probably won't be released, I find this to be one of the more outstanding songs on Confessions.<br /><br />Isaac - I have no idea what this song is about... haven't really listened to the lyrics.  Apparently it's caused a lot of ruckus among Kabbalist leaders because of who it's supposedly based on.  Whatever.  What really grabs me about it is the chorus, which has a lot of humming a la \\"Frozen.\\"  And I like that.<br /><br />Push - This song reminds me of \\"Don't Stop\\" from Bedtime Stories... maybe a tad slower BPM.  Supposedly, it's about Guy Ritchie (thanks Towleroad), which from the lyrics would make sense.  It's the most R&B sounding track on the album and has a catchy chorus.  It's okay; not an absolute favorite.  I think the chorus and bridge is what makes it.<br /><br />Like It Or Not - Yeah.  I think the album really ends with \\"Push\\" because this last one here is... well, it's gonna have to grow on me.  I really don't know what to say about it.  It's kind of how I feel about \\"Mer Girl\\" from Ray of Light.  I guess if the album were a workout, this song would be the cool down, which is really just meant to let you down easy and say, \\"Okay, thanks for coming!\\"  I mean really, does anyone truly stick around for the credits after a movie?  Maybe a little cartoon afterwards... or bloopers, but come on.<br /><br />All in all, Confessions is an incredible album.  The vocals are great - no straining, easy to sing-a-long (for those of us who like to).  Production value an A+.  Hook the ole lady up and pick up a copy of this album TODAY; it'd be a great addition to any CD collection.<br /><br />Certified QM rating: 4/5 starsn old Kylie song. Let's go dancing ya'll! <br /> <br />How High - I would say this is the most Kylie-sounding track on the album.  And it reminds me a bit of \\"Come Into My World\\" from the Fever album.  (Not lyrically of course.)  I like the lyrics though.  I know they're about what she goes through and has gone through in life, but I think a lot of us can relate in our own ways to the personal and professional life choices she sings about. Apparently it's caused a lot of ruckus among Kabbalist leaders because of who it's supposedly based on.  Whatever.  What really grabs me about it is the chorus, which has a lot of humming a la \\"Frozen.\\"  And I like that. <br /> <br />Push - This song reminds me of \\"Don't Stop\\" from Bedtime Stories... maybe a tad slower BPM.  Supposedly, it's about Guy Ritchie (thanks Towleroad), which from the lyrics would make sense.  It's the most R&B sounding track on the album and has a catchy chorus.  It's okay; not an absolute favorite.  I think the chorus and bridge is what makes it.   <br /> <br />Like It Or Not - Yeah. 1400031087|1.0|FREY'S BOOK IS HANDS DOWN THE WORST BOOK ON ADDICTION I HAVE EVER READ, AND QUITE POSSIBLY EVER WRITTEN FOR THE SIMPLE REASON THAT IT IS IN NO WAY BASED ON FACT. <br />THE AUTHOR STARTS OUT THE BOOK STATING THAT HE CAME TO ON AN AIRPLANE 20 MINUTES BEFORE IT LANDED.  HE HAD A GAPING HOLE IN THE SIDE OF HIS FACE, WAS BLEEDING FROM THE MOUTH AND HEAD, AND WAS COVERNED IN URINE, BLOOD, AND VOMIT, ETC.  FIRST OF ALL, NO MAJOR COMMERCIAL AIRLINE IS GOING TO LET SOMEONE IN THAT CONDITION ON AN AIRCRAFT.  THAT'S NOT ONLY A RULE AIRLINES FOLLOW, IT IS PART OF F.A.A REGULATIONS.  NOT TO MENTION THAT HE WAS UNATTENDED.  HE CLAIMS THAT A DOCTOR BROUGHT HIM ON, AND TOLD THE FLIGHT CREW TO JUST LET HIM SLEEP.  WHAT KIND OF A DOCTOR PUTS SOMEONE WHO IS CLEARLY IN NEED OF IMMEDIATE MEDICAL CARE ON A PLANE INSTEAD OF TREATING THEM? CERTAINLY NOT A REPECTABLE ONE-BUT HEY, THIS IS FICTION AFTER ALL. <br />I HAVE BEEN TO HAZELDON, WHERE THIS BOOK TAKES PLACE.  FREY WOULD HAVE LASTED ALL OF 1 DAY IN THIS FACILITY IF HE DID ANY OF THE THINGS THAT HE CLAIMS HE DID. I HAVE ALSO BEEN TO TWO OTHER REHABS.  IF ONE PATIENT PHYSICALLY ASSAULTS ANOTHER, HARASSES/THREATENS/INTIMIDATES ANOTHER PATIENT OR STAFF MEMBER, THEY ARE DISCHARGED IMMEDIATLEY!!!! THIS IS A 'ZERO TOLERANCE', NO QUESTIONS ASKED POLICY, UNIVERSAL AMONG REHABS.  THE FACILITY MUST PROTECT THE WELLFARE & SAFETY OF ALL PATIENTS, AND IF MR. FREY, THE WANNA-BE BADASS IS TO BE BELIEVED HE WAS A THREAT, AND WOULD HAVE BEEN REMOVED.  WHAT HE CLAIMS HE DID COULD BE LIKENED TO BEING IN A REGULAR HOSPITAL AND HAVING THE PERSON IN THE NEXT BED,WAKE UP ONE NIGHT, START TO FREAK OUT, THREATEN YOU, PHYSICALLY HURT YOU, THEN PROCEED TO TRASH ALL THE FURNITURE IN THE ROOM, AND THE HOSPITAL STAFF DO NOTHING ABOUT IT.  HE WOULD HAVE BEEN SENT TO A PSYCH WARD OR SOMETHING.  <br />HE ALSO NEVER WOULD HAVE BEEN ALLOWED IN THE REHAB TO BEGIN WITH. SOMEONE WHO IS IN THAT KIND OF SHAPE MUST GO THROUGH A MEDICALLY MANAGED DETOX THAT THIS FACILTY DOES NOT OFFER.  HE NEEDED MAJOR DENTAL SURGERY, STICHES, AND HIS NOSE RE-SET.  ONLY WHEN HE HAD HAD THIS WORK DONE WOULD HE HAVE BEEN ALLOWED IN.  PATIENTS MUST HAVE A MEDICAL CLEARANCE IN OPRDER TO BE ADDMITTED. <br />IF A PATIENT DECIDES THAT THEY ARE NOT GOING TO COMPLY WITH RULES, OR DO THE WORK THAT THEY ARE GIVEN, THEY'RE OUT-IT'S THAT SIMPLE.  THERE ARE PLENTY OF PEOPLE OUT THERE WHO DO WANT THE HELP, AND MR. FREY WAS DOING NOTHING MORE THAN TAKING UP SPACE. <br />A COUNSELOR SPENDS APPROX. 4+ YEARS IN ORDER TO BE CREDENTIALED BY THE STATE IN ORDER TO WORK IN A REHAB. IT IS A LONG, DETAILED PROCESS. NO WAY IN HELL WOULD A COUSELOR DRIVE A PATIENT TO A REHAB TO PICK UP HIS GIRLFRIEND.  HE NOT ONLY WOULD HAVE LOST HIS JOB, BUT IT WOULD HAVE ENDED HIS CAREER. <br />SO FREY ALSO CLAIMS THAT HE KILLED A PRIEST IN PARIS WHO TRIED TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF HIM IN A CHURCH RECTORY.  I WILL NEVER BE ONE TO DEFEND THA CATHOLIC CHURCH FOR ALL ITS COVER-UPS, BUT COME ON, PLEASE!! THIS PART IS JUST SO CONTRIVED AND FAKE, IT'S ALMOST LAUGHABLE. I WAS EXPECTING TO FIND AN ENLIGHTENING TAKE ON HOW TO DEAL WITH THIS, ONLY TO DISCOVER THAT FREY HAD A HIGHER POWER WHETHER HE WAS AWARE OF IT OR NOT: HE USED THE TAO;THAT WAS HIS HIGHER POWER.  <br />IT'S SAD TO THINK THAT THIS BOOK COULD HAVE BEEN AN INSPIRATION.  I STOPPED GOING TO MEETINGS FOR 2 YEARS BECAUSE I BECAME TIRED OF THEM.  I WANTED SOMETHING DIFFERNET THAT I WAS NOT GETTING FROM AA. I AM BACK THERE NOW, AND IT HAS TAKEN ON A NEW MEANING FOR ME.  I CAN SAY THAT FREY MAY HAVE HIS REASONS FOR NOT WANTING AA (EVEN THOUGH HE PRACTICED SOME OF ITS MAJOR PRICIPLES), BUT IT'S FOR ALL THE WRONG REASONS: HE DOESN'T QUITE UNDERSTAND THE PROGRAM, OR WHAT IT'S REALLY ALL ABOUT. <br />THIS BOOK IS ACTUALLY VERY MEAN SPIRITED AND SADISTIC.  FREY KNOWS THIS IS A LIE, AND HE MUST BE THE MOST UNCONSCIONABLE PERSON TO WRITE A BOOK LIKE THIS, SENDING OUT A MESSAGE OF FALSE HOPE AND LIES TO SOMEONE WHO MIGHT BE ON THE VERGE OF ASKING FOR HELP, ONLY TO DECIDE NOT TO AFTER READING THIS PIECE OF TRASH. <br /> <br />OPRAH RECCOMMENDED THIS BOOK OUT OF IGNORANCE.  SHE DOESN'T KNOW ANY BETTER.  BUT TO THOSE OF US WHO DO, IT'S CLEAR RIGHT FROM AGE 1 THIS BOOK IS BY NO MEANS AMEMIOR-NOT EVEN CLOSE. <br />I DID NOT WRITE THIS REVIEW TO BE MEAN SPIRITED, AND COMPARE MY STORY WITH FREY'S. 0596009208|5.0|We adopted this book for our first-year programming sequence at the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics.  Our students begin their programming experience learning some Python.  Both C++ and Java are bad languages to teach buck beginners.  When I taught these to beginners I spent too much time untangling syntax and not enough on the core ideas of forking, looping and recursion.  Python lays these issues bare.  It also teaches good formatting habits. <br /> <br />Since our students know how to write simple procedural programs in Python, we wanted a book that assumed that ability.  Heads First Java picks up in just the right place.  We also wanted a book that emphasizes and exploits the fact that Java is an OBJECT ORIENTED LANGUAGE.  Many books treat Java exactly as if it were C++. They push inheritance and interfaces into the late chapters of their books.  Wrong!  Polymorphism and inheritance are bread and butter topics in Java.  Heads First gives them the early coverage they deserve.   <br /> <br />This book does a good job of getting the student to think in an object-oriented way.  It is doing a good job of preparing our students for the second-year course in Data Structures and Algorithms.

0060930187|4.0|Sylvia Plath was one of the most gifted young poets of her generation. ARIEL, by far her finest work, was completed just days before she committed suicide in 1963 at the age of thirty.<br /><br />More widely read is her novel THE BELL JAR, written between 1958 and 1962, and published only six weeks before her death. Less a novel than a thinly fictionalized memoir of her first suicide attempt at age twenty, THE BELL JAR has become a feminist manifesto supposedly chronicling the frustrated hopes of a young woman held a virtual prisoner by an uncaring society.<br /><br />Plath's posthumous adoption by the feminist movement largely obscured the fineness of her writing and the truth about her life. As her daughter, Frieda Rebecca Hughes has acidly observed, Plath became a \\"suicide doll\\" for an intellectual movement seeking real-life martyrs. This turn of circumstance has long frustrated readers and critics who wish to assess Plath on her own terms.<br /><br />It is clear from a close reading of THE BELL JAR that Sylvia Plath was a complex, brilliant, unbalanced, creative and ultimately self-destructive person. On the one hand it is tragic that Plath ended her life before antidepressant drug therapies came into use, possibly regulating her lifelong history of extreme mood swings; on the other, medications may have subdued the brilliance and passion that underlie this book and the ARIEL poems.<br /><br />As THE BELL JAR begins we find young \\"Esther Greenwood\\" spending a summer in New York City as a student \\"guest editor\\" at a major women's magazine.<br /><br />Plath spares no effort in underlining the fact that this experience, with its exposure to the broad but not always genteel cultural and social mileu that is New York City horrifies Esther, an overprotected suburban girl to the tips of her well-shined saddle shoes. What another girl might find exotic or exciting about New York, Esther finds utterly repugnant.<br /><br />Her innocence leads her into several unpleasant encounters with men, and several scathing confrontations with the other girls in her group as well as the editor of the magazine, Jay Cee, whose pointed comments are almost uniformly unkind.<br /><br />Plath admittedly caricatured and lampooned real people throughout THE BELL JAR, cruelly and so much so that she published it under a pseudonym, \\"Victoria Lucas\\" in Britain, and felt that it should never be published in the United States. Her mother, with whom she had a symbiotic and mutually supportive relationship, appears in THE BELL JAR as a thick-headed ogre, largely blind to Esther's travails.<br /><br />Esther herself is a supremely gifted but supremely self-involved person whose constant internal dialogue effectively blots out much of the world around her. She is far less sensitive to the wants and needs of others than to her own feelings, of which even the most transitory or irrational are paramount. If Plath's Esther is a caricature, then she was the most cruel of all to herself. If Esther is an honest portrait, then Plath presents herself as a temperamental overachiever and a person who neither liked others nor was particularly likeable, at least at age twenty.<br /><br />Esther is like many depressed young people. She is unable to see any way out of her immediate unhappiness other than killing herself. Her contemplation of self-destruction, the actual attempt, and her long, slow painful recovery are recounted in searingly sad detail. The writing is simple but poignant.<br /><br />Throughout the book Sylvia Plath/Esther Greenwood laments that she is heremetically sealed within a bell jar, unable to have meaningful contact with life. Esther freely admits her terror of choices. To choose one path is to allow all the roads not taken to darken forever.<br /><br />These are thoughts that pass through every young mind, but they have rarely been committed to paper so well. GIRL, INTERRUPTED by Susanna Kaysen (which very coincidentally takes place in roughly the same era and in the same private psychiatric hospital) is but a pale shadow of THE BELL JAR.<br /><br />Dredging all this pain and reexamining this time in her life may not have been the best personal choice for Sylvia Plath, whose bell jar did descend again, and with finality. Plath fell into a deep depression during the writing of THE BELL JAR. Her personal life collapsed. She became increasingly isolated from those around her, even while she wrote the poems of ARIEL in a white heat, sometimes at the rate of two a day. She finally succeeded in taking her own life on February 11, 1963.BELL JAR.    Dredging all this pain and reexamining this time in her life may not have been the best personal choice for Sylvia Plath, whose bell jar did descend again, and with finality. Plath fell into a deep depression during the writing of THE BELL JAR. Her personal life collapsed. She became increasingly isolated from those around her, even while she wrote the poems of ARIEL in a white heat, sometimes at the rate of two a day. She finally succeeded in taking her own life on February 11, 1963.
0060723513|2.0|Being interested in things Australian, I welcomed the offer to borrow this book from a coworker who also enjoys reading books about Australia.  She had told me this was a true story.  It disturbed me somewhat by the end of it, so I'm glad to hear it was fiction. <br /> <br />It reads very well.  It's a quick read. And that's the positive. <br /> <br />It also presented the Aboriginal practices in such a way that is fascinating.  Being that I know very little about the Aboriginal culture, I cannot comment as to whether this is fact or not, but I'm willing to believe the people on here who say it isn't. <br /> <br />Why? <br /> <br />Because parts of the book were either unbelievable or disappointing. <br /> <br />I haven't read this in a while, but wasn't she teaching a course on Aboriginal culture before she was \\"invited\\" to join them?  Didn't she have a clue that she might end up somewhere where high heels and a dress wouldn't be appropriate? <br /> <br />The ending of the book really bothered me.  Here was a woman who spent weeks with these people and supposedly became one with them.  She explicitly says many times how much the Aboriginals tolerate the civilized people no matter what (whether this is true or not is besides the point - she says it over and over), but yet....  But yet, when she returns to civilization, rather than take the open mindedness that the Aboriginals seemed to have ingraned in her (which she needed in order to accept many of the rituals and practices they had asked her to partake in), she becomes rudly intolerant for the \\"civilized\\" culture for not believing what had happened to her.  She goes as far as to call them narrow minded for not even accepting what had happened to her, and in the end she moves out of Australia and back to the US out of frustration. <br /> <br />This bothered me.  This reminds me of Michael Crighton's autobiographical book about his own spiritual journeys.  Every chapter would start with him being impatient and intolerant of his environment (whatever it would be).  Then by the end of the chapter he would become more tolerant.  By the end of the chapter the reader would have seen how much he had learned and grown from that experience.  But then the next chapter would begin and he'd be back to his unsympathetic ways. <br /> <br />This is what I saw here.  This woman had been around a patient, serene culture that took no urgency to teach her that there's more to life.  Instead of taking that patience and that tolerance back to her own world, she was nasty and negative and frustrated.  Whether this book is true or not, is not the point at this stage.  As a human being this \\"character\\" learned nothing but to be arrogant about her own experience, instead of accepting of the fact that no everyone is going to believe her account.
B000BTJDGC|5.0|The Exorcism of Emily Rose was, in my opinion (and I've researched many exorcism cases for my horror novels) one of the most accurate portrayals of  what an actual possession case would look like.    The movie is exactly what the writers and producers held it out to be. It focuses on the trial of the priest who presided over the exorcism, not the exorcism itself.    Although the possession and the exorcism are shown in flashback, the focus is more on the court case following it, which I thought was an outstanding idea.    For those of you, and there were many in the theater, who want the high make-up special effect-laiden horror you won't find it here.     For those of you who want a movie that  does what all good movies do, provoke a discussion that lasts long after the movie is over, here you have it.    The movie, in the court room, does a fantastic job of explaining what happened to the girl both from the religious and the non-religious point of view.     To compare this to The Exorcist would be an injustice. This is a movie that, in its own right, deserves to stand as one of the better made horror films in recent history.

B000002BFL|4.0|Every self styled music critic has a at least a few \\"black sheep\\" albums they hold in special esteem. As frustrating as it is that they don't receive the public and critical acclaim deserved, there is something in our selfish nature that takes pride in being among a small group of enlightened admirers. \\"The Ghost of Tom Joad\\" is one of mine. Gloriously unnoticed and largely forgotten amidst the colossus of the Springsteen catalogue, I'm hard pressed to think of any other album I'd rather hear in a reflective/ melancholy,  idle mid-week evening, sort of mood.<br /><br />The album title of course presupposes a lot in it's reference to Steinbeck's \\"The Grapes of Wrath\\". As such it could easily be expected to fall into the realm of unforgivably overblown, self importance and frivolity. Likely a lesser musician would have been mired with such a facetious approach, and produce a laughably forgettable outcome. Fortunately Bruce's integrity and conviction prevent any atrophy of craftsmanship, and the album does proud the social legacy of G.O.W<br /><br />The songs contain unforgettable characters and stories with workman like artistry. Fitted with subtle guitar arrangements and occasional harmonic explosions, the music never detracts from the lyrics, which are the driving agent here. Much like Nebraska (another introspective folky piece a decade previous) Tom Joad shines with a slow burning, hard earned beauty which invites repeated exposure. The difference is breadth of perspective, which runs from introverted analysis to a larger social commentary, and thus establishes a more timeless appeal than does Nebraska. Also the musicianship is on a higher level here.<br /><br />Standouts include Highway 29, a stunning mood piece of a song, with such a wistfully tremendous finish-\\"I told myself it was all something in her, but as we drove I knew it was something in me\\" and \\"I closed my eyes and I was running, yeah I was running, then I was flyin\\". The Line, an exploration of poverty and destitution, could elicit emotion from a rock -\\"They risk death in the deserts and mountains, we send 'em home and they come right back again, Carl hunger is a powerful thing.\\"<br /><br />Straight Time, Youngstown, Sinaloa Cowboys, and the Title track are also all absolute stand outs. The Springsteenesque themes of social repression, political indifference, human resilience, and a general consensus of `history to the defeated' are explored with brilliant panache here.<br /><br />In a fall 05 interview with Rolling Stone, Bono pride fully stated \\"If Dylan is Faulkner, then Springsteen is Steinbeck\\". Opinions aside, that statement seems relevant to this review.<br /><br />And for what it's worth; I agree.stitution, could elicit emotion from a rock -\\"They risk death in the deserts and mountains, we send 'em home and they come right back again, Carl hunger is a powerful thing.\\"  <br />Straight Time, Youngstown, Sinaloa Cowboys, and the Title track are also all absolute stand outs. The Springsteenesque themes of social repression, political indifference, human resilience, and a general consensus of `history to the defeated' are explored with brilliant panache here.  <br />In a fall 05 interview with Rolling Stone, Bono pride fully stated \\"If Dylan is Faulkner, then Springsteen is Steinbeck\\". Opinions aside, that statement seems relevant to this review.  <br />And for what it's worth; I agree.    <br />
